funder.name: Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service

abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Hybridisation can lead to the formation of new evolutionary lineages and some described insect species may in fact be first‐generation hybrids of their parental species. <jats:italic>Anoplistes forticornis</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>A</jats:italic>. <jats:italic>galusoi</jats:italic> are two closely related cerambycid taxa endemic to Central Asia that exhibit a peculiar geographical distribution. Although the common diagnostic elytral pattern makes these beetles superficially easily distinguishable, there are marked resemblances in their morphology. By applying an integrative taxonomy approach, we verify the taxonomic status of <jats:italic>A</jats:italic>. <jats:italic>forticornis</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>A</jats:italic>. <jats:italic>galusoi</jats:italic> and test the possibility of hybridisation. The results of our comprehensive morphological examination and molecular analyses targeting mitochondrial (COI, 16S rRNA) and nuclear (arginine kinase, CAD, 28S rRNA) genes support the specific status of these taxa. In mtDNA, the putative hybrid specimen is more closely related to <jats:italic>A</jats:italic>. <jats:italic>forticornis</jats:italic>, which indicates that a female of this species bred with a male of <jats:italic>A</jats:italic>. <jats:italic>galusoi</jats:italic>. The supposed ecotypic variability (manifested in elytral pattern) is apparently not related to the topography or spatial structure of habitat. The phylogenetic hypothesis supports a peripatric scenario in which populations of the common ancestor had been separated for a significant period of time, first by the mountain ranges of Dzungarian Alatau (~11–10 Ma) and ultimately by the Ili River. The diverged taxa came into recent secondary contact following these isolation events. The methodology presented herein can be widely applied to identify first‐generation hybridisation in Coleoptera.</jats:p>
title: Integrative taxonomy tests possible hybridisation between Central Asian cerambycids (Coleoptera)
